questions.text: Which of these is a grievous hurt?

options.label: A
options.text: Incised looking laceration over forehead

options.label: B
options.text: Severe bodily pain for 10 days with inability to do even basic activities like taking bath

options.label: C
options.text: Abrasion over cheek

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B

questions.correct_answer: A. Incised looking laceration over forehead
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Incised looking laceration over forehead

questions.text: One person was found dead due to stab injury at his home. The Neighbor saw the victim’s elder brother with a knife on the same day near victim’s house. This is what type of evidence?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct Evidence

options.label: B
options.text: Circumstantial Evidence

options.label: C
options.text: Hearsay Evidence

options.label: D
options.text: Dying Declaration

questions.correct_answer: B. Circumstantial Evidence
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Circumstantial Evidence

questions.text: In a case of death due to alleged poisoning, the prosecution presents a toxicology report which mentions that the victim’s body had toxic substance based on the analysis of the stomach contents. Which of the below statement is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The toxicology report is inadmissible as the toxicologist himself is not present in the court.

options.label: B
options.text: The toxicology report is admissible as an exception to requirement of oral evidence, provided, toxicologist verified his findings with autopsy surgeon.

options.label: C
options.text: The toxicology report is admissible only if it can be corroborated by a common witness who had first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition.

options.label: D
options.text: The toxicology report is admissible without oral evidence as the findings in such reports are typically more objective rather than subjective interpretation by the expert.

questions.correct_answer: D. The toxicology report is admissible without oral evidence as the findings in such reports are typically more objective rather than subjective interpretation by the expert.
questions.explanation: Ans. D) The toxicology report is admissible without oral evidence as the findings in such reports are typically more objective rather than subjective interpretation by the expert.

questions.text: In a criminal trial, the prosecution calls a witness who initially agrees to testify but then becomes evasive and refuses to cooperate, contradicting prior statements. The prosecutor seeks permission to ask leading questions during examination-in-chief. Under what circumstance can this be allowed?

options.label: A
options.text: A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is an expert in the subject matter of the case.

options.label: B
options.text: A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.

options.label: C
options.text: A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the evidence of witness fails to prove that accused has done the crime.

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C

questions.correct_answer: B. A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man married for 5 years was found deceased under suspicious circumstances in a rented apartment in Mumbai. According to the Indian legal process, which type of inquest will be done?

options.label: A
options.text: Police inquest

options.label: B
options.text: Magistrate inquest

options.label: C
options.text: Coroner inquest

options.label: D
options.text: Medical examiner’s inquest

questions.correct_answer: A. Police inquest
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Police Inquest

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is found dead in her marital home under suspicious circumstances. She had been married for 5 years, and her family reports a history of dowry demands from her in-laws. Who is responsible for conducting the official inquiry in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Judicial Magistrate

options.label: B
options.text: Executive Magistrate

options.label: C
options.text: Police IG

options.label: D
options.text: Head Constable

questions.correct_answer: B. Executive Magistrate
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Executive Magistrate

questions.text: A 20-year-old sexual assault victim is examined in a courtroom setting described as "in camera." What does this imply about the nature of the court proceedings?

options.label: A
options.text: Open proceeding

options.label: B
options.text: Closed proceeding

options.label: C
options.text: Recorded in camera

options.label: D
options.text: Proceedings in another place

questions.correct_answer: B. Closed proceeding
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Closed proceeding

questions.text: A neurosurgeon at a private hospital has a standing agreement with a referring primary care physician. For every patient referred to the neurosurgeon, the primary care physician receives a certain percentage of the surgical fee. This arrangement has come under scrutiny during a routine audit by the healthcare regulatory authority. What is this controversial practice called?

options.label: A
options.text: Conduct money

options.label: B
options.text: Dichotomy

options.label: C
options.text: Filing an FIR against the patient for not paying the fee

options.label: D
options.text: Res ipsa loquitur

questions.correct_answer: B. Dichotomy
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Dichotomy

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor, who bears the onus of proof?

options.label: A
options.text: Patient

options.label: B
options.text: Police not under rank of sub inspector

options.label: C
options.text: Magistrate

options.label: D
options.text: Doctor

questions.correct_answer: A. Patient
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Patient

questions.text: Why does the onus of proof lie on the doctor rather than the patient in cases of res ipsa loquitur in medical negligence?

options.label: A
options.text: The doctor is a trained professional who has direct control over the procedure, making it easier for them to explain what went wrong.

options.label: B
options.text: Res ipsa loquitur is a principle where the nature of the injury itself suggests negligence, which makes it the doctor's responsibility to prove they acted correctly.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient is presumed to be too inexperienced to understand the medical procedure and cannot prove negligence on their own.

options.label: D
options.text: In medical negligence cases, the law assumes the patient has no right to challenge the doctor’s actions due to the doctor’s superior knowledge.

questions.correct_answer: B. Res ipsa loquitur is a principle where the nature of the injury itself suggests negligence, which makes it the doctor's responsibility to prove they acted correctly.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Res ipsa loquitur is a principle where the nature of the injury itself suggests negligence, which makes it the doctor's responsibility to prove they acted correctly

questions.text: A 40-year-old man undergoes a routine cataract surgery in his right eye. After the surgery, he experiences significant and sudden vision loss in the operated eye. Further investigation reveals that the surgeon mistakenly operated on the wrong eye. The patient files a civil lawsuit against the surgeon for medical negligence. In this case, which of the following is correct regarding the burden of proof?

options.label: A
options.text: Burden of proof lies on patient to prove that surgeon was negligent in operating on wrong eye.

options.label: B
options.text: Burden of proof lies on surgeon to prove that operating on wrong eye was not due to negligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Burden of proof lies on both patient and surgeon as it is a case of contributory negligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Burden of proof lies on patient to prove that surgeon’s actions directly led to the vision loss.

questions.correct_answer: B. Burden of proof lies on surgeon to prove that operating on wrong eye was not due to negligence.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Burden of proof lies on surgeon to prove that operating on wrong eye was not due to negligence.

questions.text: Medical etiquette refers to:

options.label: A
options.text: The legal obligations and contracts between doctors

options.label: B
options.text: The respectful behavior and professional courtesy between doctors

options.label: C
options.text: The moral principles that guide doctor-patient interactions

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B

questions.correct_answer: B. The respectful behavior and professional courtesy between doctors
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The respectful behavior and professional courtesy between doctors

questions.text: In a legal case involving a patient's medical treatment, the court requires information about the patient's medical condition and treatment history. Under which legal concept can professional secrecy be divulged in a court of law without violating ethical standards?

options.label: A
options.text: Doctrine of Common Knowledge

options.label: B
options.text: Privileged communications

options.label: C
options.text: Res ipsa loquitor

options.label: D
options.text: Therapeutic privilege

questions.correct_answer: B. Privileged communications
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Privileged communications

questions.text: A patient, Mr. X, undergoes surgery for a hernia at a hospital. During the procedure, the surgeon, Dr. Y, inadvertently makes a small incision that causes internal bleeding. Dr. Y admits that this mistake was a result of his negligence during the surgery. However, Dr. Y argues that the patient, Mr. X, contributed to the injury as he failed to follow the post-operative care instructions, such as refraining from heavy lifting, which led to complications. Who has the onus to prove that the patient was also negligent?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient, because they must prove that their actions did not contribute to the injury.

options.label: B
options.text: The doctor, because they admitted to negligence and must prove that the patient's actions contributed to the injury.

options.label: C
options.text: The court, because it must determine the extent of both parties' negligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Patient has the onus to prove that he was not negligent and doctor has the onus to prove that patient was negligent

questions.correct_answer: B. The doctor, because they admitted to negligence and must prove that the patient's actions contributed to the injury.
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: How can human hair be differentiated from animal hair based on the medulla?

options.label: A
options.text: The medulla in human hair is often absent or fragmented, whereas in animal hair, it is continuous and prominent.

options.label: B
options.text: The medulla in human hair is thicker and darker compared to animal hair.

options.label: C
options.text: Animal hair has a medulla that is always absent, while human hair always has a visible medulla.

options.label: D
options.text: The medulla in human hair is solid and opaque, whereas animal hair has a hollow medulla.

questions.correct_answer: A. The medulla in human hair is often absent or fragmented, whereas in animal hair, it is continuous and prominent.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) The medulla in human hair is often absent or fragmented, whereas in animal hair, it is continuous and prominent.

questions.text: Why is anthropometry more useful in adults than in children?

options.label: A
options.text: Adult body proportions are more consistent and stable, while children's bodies undergo rapid changes during growth, leading to less predictable measurements.

options.label: B
options.text: Anthropometric measurements in children are more influenced by environmental factors, making them less accurate for forensic purposes than in adults.

options.label: C
options.text: Adult bone structure is more developed and easier to measure accurately compared to children's bones, which are still in a stage of growth and ossification.

options.label: D
options.text: Children have smaller body sizes, making it difficult to obtain accurate anthropometric measurements, which is easier with adults

questions.correct_answer: A. Adult body proportions are more consistent and stable, while children's bodies undergo rapid changes during growth, leading to less predictable measurements.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Adult body proportions are more consistent and stable, while children's bodies undergo rapid changes during growth, leading to less predictable measurements

questions.text: First permanent teeth to erupt?

options.label: A
options.text: Permanent 1 st Molar

options.label: B
options.text: Permanent Central Incisor

options.label: C
options.text: Permanent Lateral incisor

options.label: D
options.text: Permanent Canine

questions.correct_answer: A. Permanent 1 st Molar
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Permanent 1stMolar

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the fingerprints is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Left and right hand prints of an individual are identical; only the orientation of the hand changes.

options.label: B
options.text: Fingerprints are mostly full formed before birth, but keeps undergoing further refinement by adolescence, so not much helpful in childhood for identification

options.label: C
options.text: The probability of two individuals having identical fingerprints is practically zero, even for identical twins.

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C

questions.correct_answer: C. The probability of two individuals having identical fingerprints is practically zero, even for identical twins.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) The probability of two individuals having identical fingerprints is practically zero, even for identical twins.

questions.text: Which is the most important reason for preferring Letulle’s technique of autopsy in infants, particularly when congenital anomalies are suspected?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves removal of the brain first, which allows for better preservation of the cranial contents in cases of congenital abnormalities.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to preserve the relationship between the organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in organ positioning or malformations without disturbing their natural anatomical arrangement.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows opening the chest and abdominal cavities in sequence, which helps to better identify congenital anomalies, as compared to other techniques like Ghon's, Virchow's, or Rokitansky's.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves the dissection of the spinal cord first, which is particularly useful for detecting vertebral column abnormalities that may be present in infants with congenital malformations.

questions.correct_answer: B. It helps to preserve the relationship between the organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in organ positioning or malformations without disturbing their natural anatomical arrangement.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) It helps to preserve the relationship between the organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in organ positioning or malformations without disturbing their natural anatomical arrangement.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with involuntary suspended animation? Electrocution Yoga Practitioners Drowning Burn

options.label: A
options.text: 1 and 2

options.label: B
options.text: 1 and 3

options.label: C
options.text: 2 and 4

options.label: D
options.text: 1, 2 and 3

questions.correct_answer: B. 1 and 3
questions.explanation: Ans. B) 1 and 3

questions.text: A 35-year-old male suffering from tetanus dies. His body temperature is measured at 38.5°C six hours post-mortem, while the surrounding room temperature is 22°C. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the elevated body temperature after death in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Post-mortem rigor mortis due to tetanic spasms

options.label: B
options.text: Heat retention due to muscle activity before death from tetanus

options.label: C
options.text: Post-mortem caloricity due to a hypermetabolic state caused by tetanus infection before death

options.label: D
options.text: Bacterial decomposition leading to heat production after death

questions.correct_answer: B. Heat retention due to muscle activity before death from tetanus
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: What type of smell is produced by the decomposed body from the given image?

options.label: A
options.text: Ammoniacal

options.label: B
options.text: Odorless

options.label: C
options.text: Offensive

options.label: D
options.text: Garlicky

questions.correct_answer: B. Odorless
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Odorless

questions.text: Which of the following best favours Adipocere formation?

options.label: A
options.text: Moderately warm temperature, stagnant water and anaerobic environment

options.label: B
options.text: Moderately warm temperature, running water and anaerobic environment

options.label: C
options.text: Moderately warm temperature, stagnant water and aerobic environment

options.label: D
options.text: Extremely high temperature, stagnant water and anaerobic environment

questions.correct_answer: A. Moderately warm temperature, stagnant water and anaerobic environment
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Moderately warm temperature, stagnant water, and anaerobic environment.

questions.text: A body is discovered in an isolated, dry cave with minimal airflow, high temperatures, and low humidity. After several months, the body shows signs of mummification, with the skin and organs becoming dry and leathery. What is the primary cause of this preservation process?

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid dehydration due to high temperature and low humidity, preventing bacterial decomposition

options.label: B
options.text: Low temperature and low humidity, reducing the rate of enzymatic breakdown and slowing decomposition

options.label: C
options.text: High temperature causing accelerated autolysis, while dehydration of tissues leads to preservation

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of airflow causing accumulation of toxins and metabolic waste, inhibiting bacterial growth and decay

questions.correct_answer: A. Rapid dehydration due to high temperature and low humidity, preventing bacterial decomposition
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A body is discovered two weeks after death in a warm, humid environment. Upon examination, the body is found to be bloated and floating in a shallow pond. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the body floating in the water?

options.label: A
options.text: Air trapped in the lungs due to the drowning process during life

options.label: B
options.text: Post-mortem bacterial decomposition producing gases that accumulate in the body cavities, leading to buoyancy

options.label: C
options.text: Post-mortem rigor mortis causing the body to stiffen, resulting in reduced density and allowing it to float

options.label: D
options.text: Body fluids accumulating in the tissues due to tissue necrosis and post-mortem changes, increasing body weight and reducing buoyancy

questions.correct_answer: B. Post-mortem bacterial decomposition producing gases that accumulate in the body cavities, leading to buoyancy
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Post-mortem bacterial decomposition producing gases that accumulate in the body cavities, leading to buoyancy

questions.text: What is the primary cause of scab formation in an abrasion?

options.label: A
options.text: Clotting of blood on the surface of the skin.

options.label: B
options.text: The death of skin cells due to friction, leading to the hardening of the skin's surface.

options.label: C
options.text: The accumulation of dead skin cells that causes the skin to peel and form a protective layer.

options.label: D
options.text: The body's immune response to the abrasion, which leads to the production of pus that dries into a scab.

questions.correct_answer: A. Clotting of blood on the surface of the skin.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Clotting of blood on the surface of the skin.

questions.text: Likely age of bruise?

options.label: A
options.text: Few hours

options.label: B
options.text: 2-3 days

options.label: C
options.text: 7-14 days

options.label: D
options.text: 21-28 days

questions.correct_answer: C. 7-14 days
questions.explanation: Ans. C)

questions.text: Direction of Impact in the image below?

options.label: A
options.text: Elbow to shoulder

options.label: B
options.text: Shoulder to elbow

options.label: C
options.text: Right to left side of arm

options.label: D
options.text: Left to right side of arm

questions.correct_answer: B. Shoulder to elbow
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Shoulder to elbow

questions.text: A forensic investigator is examining a series of bruises on a victim's body. To determine whether these bruises are artificial or true bruises, which of the following characteristics would be most useful to assess?

options.label: A
options.text: Color changes over time

options.label: B
options.text: Size of the bruise

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of underlying bone fractures

options.label: D
options.text: Victim's medical history

questions.correct_answer: A. Color changes over time
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Color changes over time

questions.text: Avulsion is a type of:

options.label: A
options.text: Chop wound

options.label: B
options.text: Incised wound

options.label: C
options.text: Laceration

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

questions.correct_answer: C. Laceration
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Laceration

questions.text: Why is sweating absent in heat stroke?

options.label: A
options.text: The body's thermoregulatory system is overwhelmed, causing a failure of the sweat glands to function.

options.label: B
options.text: High body temperature directly inhibits the function of sweat glands, preventing sweating.

options.label: C
options.text: Dehydration from excessive sweating leads to an inability to sweat during heat stroke.

options.label: D
options.text: The hypothalamus shuts down sweat production as a defense mechanism to preserve body fluids.

questions.correct_answer: A. The body's thermoregulatory system is overwhelmed, causing a failure of the sweat glands to function.
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: Why does muscle contraction occur during rigor mortis, and why can it not relax?

options.label: A
options.text: Postmortem breakdown of the sarcoplasmic reticulum releases calcium ions, initiating muscle contraction, while the inability to produce ATP prevents the detachment of actin-myosin cross-bridges.

options.label: B
options.text: Depletion of ATP after death causes the myosin heads to remain attached to actin, leading to muscle contraction, but the absence of calcium prevents relaxation.

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium ions are released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum due to cellular damage after death, causing muscle contraction; however, ATP is required to prevent excessive contraction by facilitating cross-bridge detachment.

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of ATP after death causes calcium to be pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, preventing contraction, but without ATP, myosin heads cannot detach, preventing relaxation.

questions.correct_answer: A. Postmortem breakdown of the sarcoplasmic reticulum releases calcium ions, initiating muscle contraction, while the inability to produce ATP prevents the detachment of actin-myosin cross-bridges.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Postmortem breakdown of the sarcoplasmic reticulum releases calcium ions, initiating muscle contraction, while the inability to produce ATP prevents the detachment of actin-myosin cross-bridges.

questions.text: "Molotov cocktail" is best characterized as?

options.label: A
options.text: A mixed-device bomb

options.label: B
options.text: A simple petrol bomb thrown by hand

options.label: C
options.text: Named after the Molotov, a foreign minister of Russia, who died after consuming a cocktail

options.label: D
options.text: A type of tank

questions.correct_answer: B. A simple petrol bomb thrown by hand
questions.explanation: Ans. B) A simple petrol bomb thrown by hand

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism behind Joule burns in electrical injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct thermal injury caused by contact with source of electrical current

options.label: B
options.text: Localized muscle spasms due to electrical currents causing internal friction

options.label: C
options.text: Heat generated by the resistance of tissues to the electrical current

options.label: D
options.text: Vascular injury resulting from rapid cooling of tissue after electrical exposure

questions.correct_answer: C. Heat generated by the resistance of tissues to the electrical current
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Heat generated by the resistance of tissues to the electrical current

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for frostbite?

options.label: A
options.text: Quickly Rewarming the affected area with hot water

options.label: B
options.text: Massaging the frozen tissue to improve blood flow

options.label: C
options.text: Gradually rewarming the affected area with warm (not hot) water

options.label: D
options.text: Using ice packs to prevent further tissue damage

questions.correct_answer: C. Gradually rewarming the affected area with warm (not hot) water
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Gradually rewarming the affected area with warm (not hot) water

questions.text: Which is a feature of bruise?

options.label: A
options.text: Occurs only in dependent parts

options.label: B
options.text: Edges are clearly defined

options.label: C
options.text: Absent in areas of body under pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Extravasation of blood into surrounding tissues occur

questions.correct_answer: D. Extravasation of blood into surrounding tissues occur
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Extravasation of blood into surrounding tissues occur

questions.text: Why are rib fractures very common in Shaken Baby Syndrome (SBS)?

options.label: A
options.text: The rib cage in infants is highly mineralized, making it more prone to fractures during shaking.

options.label: B
options.text: Rib fractures occur due to direct blows to the chest during the shaking process.

options.label: C
options.text: Infant rib cages are soft and flexible, making them more vulnerable to fractures from the compressive forces of shaking.

options.label: D
options.text: Rib fractures are caused by excessive movement of the arms and legs during shaking, not from pressure on the chest.

questions.correct_answer: C. Infant rib cages are soft and flexible, making them more vulnerable to fractures from the compressive forces of shaking.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Infant rib cages are soft and flexible, making them more vulnerable to fractures from the compressive forces of shaking.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Marshall’s triad in relation to explosive injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: Marshall's triad consists of burns, fractures, and internal bleeding.

options.label: B
options.text: Marshall's triad includes fractures, dislocations, and bruises.

options.label: C
options.text: Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.

options.label: D
options.text: Marshall's triad consists of head trauma, chest trauma, and abdominal trauma.

questions.correct_answer: C. Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the pediatric clinic for the third time this month, claiming her 4-year-old child has a history of unexplained vomiting, diarrhea, and recurrent respiratory infections. The child has undergone numerous unnecessary tests, and no organic cause has been found. The mother presents as overly attentive and eager to participate in the child's care but becomes defensive and anxious when questioned about the child's condition. What is the most likely underlying cause of this mother’s behavior in Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy (MSBP)?

options.label: A
options.text: Unresolved childhood trauma and attachment issues that drive the caregiver to seek attention and control through the child’s illness.

options.label: B
options.text: Excessive anxiety and fear of losing parental control, leading to over-involvement in the child’s medical care.

options.label: C
options.text: Personality disorders, particularly narcissistic personality disorder, which leads the caregiver to fabricate symptoms to receive admiration and attention from others.

options.label: D
options.text: Cognitive distortions and delusional thinking, which cause the caregiver to genuinely believe that the child is sick, even when no medical evidence supports the claims.

questions.correct_answer: A. Unresolved childhood trauma and attachment issues that drive the caregiver to seek attention and control through the child’s illness.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Unresolved childhood trauma and attachment issues that drive the caregiver to seek attention and control through the child’s illness.

questions.text: A forensic expert is reviewing autopsy reports for a series of asphyxiation cases. In the course of this review, the expert is aware that certain methods of asphyxiation carry a higher suspicion of homicidal intent due to their nature and the circumstances under which they typically occur. Which method of asphyxiation listed below is almost always considered to be homicidal in nature?

options.label: A
options.text: Gagging

options.label: B
options.text: Overlaying

options.label: C
options.text: Smothering

options.label: D
options.text: Choking

questions.correct_answer: A. Gagging
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Gagging

questions.text: Which of the following is False about gunshot wound?

options.label: A
options.text: Entry wound is usually smaller than exit wound

options.label: B
options.text: Contact shot on skull in entry wound have everted margins

options.label: C
options.text: Grease collar is present at exit wound

options.label: D
options.text: Rarely Abrasion collar may be seen in exit wound

questions.correct_answer: C. Grease collar is present at exit wound
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with headache, dizziness, and confusion following prolonged exposure to carbon monoxide from a malfunctioning heater. On examination, her skin has a cherry-red appearance, and her blood sample shows a normal PaO2 but an elevated level of carboxyhemoglobin. What is the most likely cause of the cherry-red color in carbon monoxide poisoning?

options.label: A
options.text: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin with a much higher affinity than oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin, which has a cherry-red color due to its unique absorption of light.

options.label: B
options.text: Carbon monoxide directly affects the mitochondria, leading to cyanosis and reduced oxygen delivery, which causes the cherry-red color as a result of decreased tissue oxygenation.

options.label: C
options.text: Carboxyhemoglobin forms due to carbon monoxide binding to cytochrome oxidase in the mitochondria, causing a red pigmentation in the blood.

options.label: D
options.text: The cherry-red color in carbon monoxide poisoning results from increased oxygen binding to carboxyhemoglobin, causing a more efficient oxygen transport despite the inhibition of oxygen release at the tissue level.

questions.correct_answer: A. Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin with a much higher affinity than oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin, which has a cherry-red color due to its unique absorption of light.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin with a much higher affinity than oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin, which has a cherry-red color due to its unique absorption of light.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with cyanosis, tachypnea, and chocolate-brown colored blood following exposure to nitrates. A blood gas analysis reveals a normal PaO2, but methemoglobinemia is diagnosed. What is the underlying cause of the chocolate-brown color of the blood in methemoglobinemia?

options.label: A
options.text: Methemoglobin has a decreased affinity for oxygen, causing blood to appear dark red due to reduced oxygen binding at the heme group.

options.label: B
options.text: Methemoglobin binds cyanide, leading to the formation of cyanmethemoglobin, which causes the blood to appear chocolate-brown.

options.label: C
options.text: Methemoglobin is an oxidized form of hemoglobin in which the iron is in the ferric (Fe3+) state instead of the normal ferrous (Fe2+) state, which changes its light-absorbing characteristics, causing the blood to appear chocolate-brown.

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of methemoglobin leads to hypoxia and the accumulation of carbon dioxide, which causes darkening of the blood due to carbonic acid formation.

questions.correct_answer: C. Methemoglobin is an oxidized form of hemoglobin in which the iron is in the ferric (Fe3+) state instead of the normal ferrous (Fe2+) state, which changes its light-absorbing characteristics, causing the blood to appear chocolate-brown.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Methemoglobin is an oxidized form of hemoglobin in which the iron is in the ferric (Fe3+) state instead of the normal ferrous (Fe2+) state, which changes its light-absorbing characteristics, causing the blood to appear chocolate-brown.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is found in a lake. She was unconscious with an initial ECG showing ventricular fibrillation. Considering the circumstances of freshwater drowning, what is the most likely cause of her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Total asphyxia induced by the panic and struggle in water

options.label: B
options.text: Cold water shock leading to involuntary laryngeal spasm

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid fluid shifts causing blood thickening and clot formation

options.label: D
options.text: Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance

questions.correct_answer: D. Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after ingesting methanol. He is exhibiting symptoms of metabolic acidosis, visual disturbances, and CNS depression. The physician decides to treat him with fomepizole. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of action of both ethyl alcohol and fomepizole in the treatment of methanol poisoning?

options.label: A
options.text: Both ethyl alcohol and fomepizole work by inhibiting alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the conversion of methanol into formic acid, its toxic metabolite.

options.label: B
options.text: Ethyl alcohol inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase, while fomepizole activates acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, preventing acetaldehyde accumulation in methanol toxicity.

options.label: C
options.text: Fomepizole blocks alcohol dehydrogenase, while ethyl alcohol acts by enhancing the renal excretion of formic acid.

options.label: D
options.text: Ethyl alcohol blocks methanol metabolism by competing with methanol at the level of aldehyde dehydrogenase, while fomepizole inhibits methanol metabolism at the level of cytochrome P450 enzymes.

questions.correct_answer: A. Both ethyl alcohol and fomepizole work by inhibiting alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the conversion of methanol into formic acid, its toxic metabolite.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Both ethyl alcohol and fomepizole work by inhibiting alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the conversion of methanol into formic acid, its toxic metabolite.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department after ingesting a large quantity of ethylene glycol(antifreeze). His symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and central nervous system depression. Blood work reveals elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis. The physician decides to administer fomepizole. What is the mechanism of action of fomepizole in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Fomepizole inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, preventing the conversion of acetaldehyde to acetic acid and thereby reducing toxic aldehyde buildup.

options.label: B
options.text: Fomepizole inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the conversion of ethylene glycol to its toxic metabolites, glycolic acid and oxalic acid.

options.label: C
options.text: Fomepizole enhances the renal clearance of ethylene glycol by inhibiting tubular reabsorption in the kidneys.

options.label: D
options.text: Fomepizole activates cytochrome P450 enzymes, increasing the metabolism of ethylene glycol to non-toxic metabolites.

questions.correct_answer: B. Fomepizole inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the conversion of ethylene glycol to its toxic metabolites, glycolic acid and oxalic acid.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Fomepizole inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the conversion of ethylene glycol to its toxic metabolites, glycolic acid and oxalic acid.

questions.text: The image below is diagnostic of death due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Drowning

options.label: B
options.text: Hanging

options.label: C
options.text: Morphine poisoning

options.label: D
options.text: Strangulation

questions.correct_answer: A. Drowning
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Drowning

questions.text: A botanist studying psychoactive plants collects a sample with white, large, trumpet-shaped flowers. What is the mechanism of action of this plant?

options.label: A
options.text: It contains atropine, which blocks muscarinic acetylcholine receptors, causing anticholinergic effects like dry mouth, tachycardia, and delirium.

options.label: B
options.text: It inhibits acetylcholinesterase, leading to an accumulation of acetylcholine at nicotinic and muscarinicreceptors, causing cholinergic crisis with excessive salivation and sweating.

options.label: C
options.text: It activates serotonin receptors, leading to serotonergic syndrome with hyperreflexia, hyperthermia, and agitation.

options.label: D
options.text: It bind to alpha-adrenergic receptors, leading to sympathomimetic effects like tachycardia, hypertension, and agitation.

questions.correct_answer: A. It contains atropine, which blocks muscarinic acetylcholine receptors, causing anticholinergic effects like dry mouth, tachycardia, and delirium.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) It contains atropine, which blocks muscarinic acetylcholine receptors, causing anticholinergic effects like dry mouth, tachycardia, and delirium.

questions.text: Which is associated with shot gun alone?

options.label: A
options.text: Gun powder

options.label: B
options.text: Primer

options.label: C
options.text: Projectile

options.label: D
options.text: Wads

questions.correct_answer: D. Wads
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Wads

questions.text: Identify which of the following statements is not true regarding the materials required for forensic analysis of specific poisons:

options.label: A
options.text: Vitreous humor is commonly examined for alcohol poisoning.

options.label: B
options.text: The skin is analyzed for decomposition in cases of strychnine poisoning.

options.label: C
options.text: Brain tissue is essential for detecting organophosphate poisoning.

options.label: D
options.text: Fatty tissue is primarily used for examining pesticides and insecticides.

questions.correct_answer: B. The skin is analyzed for decomposition in cases of strychnine poisoning.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The skin is analyzed for decomposition in cases of strychnine poisoning.

questions.text: Why is dribbling of saliva considered a sure sign that hanging was antemortem?

options.label: A
options.text: Dribbling of saliva only occurs when the body is in a state of rigor mortis, indicating the victim was alive at the time of hanging.

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of dribbling saliva indicates the victim was conscious and able to produce saliva before death, which suggests the hanging occurred while the person was still alive.

options.label: C
options.text: Dribbling saliva is a result of postmortem decay, which can only happen after death has occurred.

options.label: D
options.text: Dribbling of saliva occurs due to the relaxation of facial muscles, which is only possible if the victim had been dead for some time.

questions.correct_answer: B. The presence of dribbling saliva indicates the victim was conscious and able to produce saliva before death, which suggests the hanging occurred while the person was still alive.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The presence of dribbling saliva indicates the victim was conscious and able to produce saliva before death, which suggests the hanging occurred while the person was still alive

questions.text: Why do cervical vertebrae fractures occur in judicial hanging but not in other types of hanging?

options.label: A
options.text: Judicial hanging involves a high drop height, creating a significant force that can fracture the cervical vertebrae.

options.label: B
options.text: In judicial hanging, the noose is placed at a higher position on the neck, causing excessive neck rotation and subsequent fractures.

options.label: C
options.text: Judicial hanging uses a thicker rope that increases the speed of the fall, leading to greater forces on the cervical spine.

options.label: D
options.text: The intentional and precise knot placement in judicial hanging causes a quick and forceful dislocation of the cervical vertebrae.

questions.correct_answer: A. Judicial hanging involves a high drop height, creating a significant force that can fracture the cervical vertebrae.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Judicial hanging involves a high drop height, creating a significant force that can fracture the cervical vertebrae

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with symptoms of abdominal pain, constipation, and fatigue. Blood tests reveal microcytic anemia and the presence of basophilic stippling in his peripheral blood smear. The most likely explanation for the basophilic stippling in this patient with suspected lead poisoning is:

options.label: A
options.text: Lead inhibits the enzyme aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD), leading to the accumulation of porphyrin intermediates.

options.label: B
options.text: Lead disrupts ribosomal RNA processing in developing red blood cells, causing precipitation of ribosomal RNA within the cytoplasm.

options.label: C
options.text: Lead binds to the enzyme ferrochelatase, preventing the incorporation of iron into heme, causing the accumulation of ferritin.

options.label: D
options.text: Lead interferes with heme synthesis, leading to an accumulation of free heme in the blood

questions.correct_answer: B. Lead disrupts ribosomal RNA processing in developing red blood cells, causing precipitation of ribosomal RNA within the cytoplasm.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Lead disrupts ribosomal RNA processing in developing red blood cells, causing precipitation of ribosomal RNA within the cytoplasm.

questions.text: What term is used to describe an irresistible sexual desire in a male?

options.label: A
options.text: Nymphomania

options.label: B
options.text: Tribadism

options.label: C
options.text: Satyriasis

options.label: D
options.text: Sadism

questions.correct_answer: C. Satyriasis
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Satyriasis

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with severe vomiting, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and gangrene after consuming bread made with ergot-contaminated rye. On examination, she shows signs of vasospasm and cyanosis of the extremities. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the pathophysiology of ergot poisoning?

options.label: A
options.text: Ergot alkaloids bind to dopamine receptors in the central nervous system, leading to hyperactivity, hallucinations, and peripheral vasodilation.

options.label: B
options.text: Ergot alkaloids act as agonists at alpha-adrenergic receptors, causing prolonged vasoconstriction and decreased blood flow to peripheral tissues, resulting in ischemia and gangrene.

options.label: C
options.text: Ergot alkaloids inhibit acetylcholinesterase, leading to accumulation of acetylcholine at neuromuscular junctions and continuous stimulation of muscles.

options.label: D
options.text: Ergot alkaloids block serotonin reuptake, causing excessive serotonin accumulation in the synaptic cleft and leading to vasodilation and serotonin syndrome.

questions.correct_answer: B. Ergot alkaloids act as agonists at alpha-adrenergic receptors, causing prolonged vasoconstriction and decreased blood flow to peripheral tissues, resulting in ischemia and gangrene.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Ergot alkaloids act as agonists at alpha-adrenergic receptors, causing prolonged vasoconstriction and decreased blood flow to peripheral tissues, resulting in ischemia and gangrene.

questions.text: Why is the diatom test performed in suspected drowning cases?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect the presence of bacteria that are commonly found in water and may indicate drowning.

options.label: B
options.text: To identify microscopic organisms in the victim’s lungs and tissues, which can confirm that the person inhaled water.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the chemical composition of the water ingested, which helps identify the location of drowning.

options.label: D
options.text: To test for toxins in the water that may have contributed to the victim's death.

questions.correct_answer: B. To identify microscopic organisms in the victim’s lungs and tissues, which can confirm that the person inhaled water.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) To identify microscopic organisms in the victim’s lungs and tissues, which can confirm that the person inhaled water.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department after ingesting several uncrushed strychnine seeds in an attempt at self-harm. He reports no symptoms or discomfort at the time of presentation. The physician is concerned about the delayed onset of toxicity. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for why this patient is not exhibiting symptoms immediately?

options.label: A
options.text: Strychnine is rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract, but the seeds' hard coating prevents its release, delaying the onset of symptoms until the seeds are crushed or dissolved.

options.label: B
options.text: Strychnine must undergo metabolism in the liver before it can reach the bloodstream, which delays the onset of symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: Strychnine has a long half-life and requires several hours for significant accumulation in the body, meaning symptoms will not appear immediately.

options.label: D
options.text: Strychnine acts only on the central nervous system, and it can take several hours for it to cross the blood-brain barrier and produce symptoms.

questions.correct_answer: A. Strychnine is rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract, but the seeds' hard coating prevents its release, delaying the onset of symptoms until the seeds are crushed or dissolved.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Strychnine is rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract, but the seeds' hard coating prevents its release, delaying the onset of symptoms until the seeds are crushed or dissolved.

questions.text: Why are petechial hemorrhages rarely seen in drowning but common in other mechanical asphyxial deaths (e.g., strangulation or hanging)?

options.label: A
options.text: In drowning, water entering the lungs causes compression of the blood vessels in the interalveolar septa, preventing their rupture.

options.label: B
options.text: In drowning, the absence of oxygen causes blood vessels to rupture, leading to petechiae.

options.label: C
options.text: Petechial hemorrhages only occur in cases of external trauma, not asphyxiation.

options.label: D
options.text: Drowning increases blood pressure, causing widespread vessel rupture and petechiae.

questions.correct_answer: A. In drowning, water entering the lungs causes compression of the blood vessels in the interalveolar septa, preventing their rupture.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) In drowning, water entering the lungs causes compression of the blood vessels in the interalveolar septa, preventing their rupture.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after ingesting strychnine in a suicide attempt. He presents with severe muscle stiffness, painful spasms, and generalized convulsions. His blood pressure is elevated, and he is highly agitated. Given the clinical presentation, which of the following best explains the mechanism of toxicity of strychnine?

options.label: A
options.text: Strychnine inhibits the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, leading to the accumulation of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, causing continuous muscle contraction.

options.label: B
options.text: Strychnine blocks glycine receptors in the spinal cord and brainstem, leading to unchecked neuronal excitability and severe muscle spasms.

options.label: C
options.text: Strychnine inhibits gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptors, resulting in hyperexcitability of the central nervous system (CNS) and generalized seizures.

options.label: D
options.text: Strychnine binds to voltage-gated sodium channels, preventing their inactivation and causing prolonged depolarization of muscle fibers.

questions.correct_answer: B. Strychnine blocks glycine receptors in the spinal cord and brainstem, leading to unchecked neuronal excitability and severe muscle spasms.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Strychnine blocks glycine receptors in the spinal cord and brainstem, leading to unchecked neuronal excitability and severe muscle spasms.

questions.text: What is the primary cause of Paltauf's haemorrhages in drowning?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct trauma to the lungs from water entry

options.label: B
options.text: Rupture of alveolar walls due to increased pressure during forced expirations

options.label: C
options.text: Inhalation of foreign particles leading to lung irritation

options.label: D
options.text: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to water aspiration

questions.correct_answer: B. Rupture of alveolar walls due to increased pressure during forced expirations
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Rupture of alveolar walls due to increased pressure during forced expirations

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the emergency department after being stung by a scorpion. The child exhibits signs of autonomic instability, including tachycardia, hypertension, excessive salivation, and muscle twitching. The medical team administers prazosin as part of the treatment. Which of the following best explains why prazosin is used in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Prazosin is a selective α-2 adrenergic antagonist that inhibits sympathetic outflow, reducing the excessive catecholamine release caused by scorpion venom.

options.label: B
options.text: Prazosin is an α-1 adrenergic antagonist that causes vasodilation and reduces the excessive vasoconstriction and hypertension caused by autonomic dysfunction after a scorpion sting.

options.label: C
options.text: Prazosin is a non-selective adrenergic antagonist that inhibits both α-1 and β-1 adrenergic receptors, decreasing both vasoconstriction and heart rate.

options.label: D
options.text: Prazosin is a direct nitric oxide donor that causes vasodilation, reducing the systemic vascular resistance and mitigating the symptoms of scorpion envenomation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Prazosin is an α-1 adrenergic antagonist that causes vasodilation and reduces the excessive vasoconstriction and hypertension caused by autonomic dysfunction after a scorpion sting.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Prazosin is an α-1 adrenergic antagonist that causes vasodilation and reduces the excessive vasoconstriction and hypertension caused by autonomic dysfunction after a scorpion sting.

questions.text: A stain is found on the clothes of a kidnapper. It is treated with picric acid and studied under a microscope which shows yellow color needle shaped crystals. What could the stain be?

options.label: A
options.text: Sputum

options.label: B
options.text: Semen

options.label: C
options.text: Blood

options.label: D
options.text: CSF

questions.correct_answer: B. Semen
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Semen

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents with the following symptoms after accidental exposure to pesticides: dizziness, muscle twitching, and generalized weakness. On examination, the patient shows hyperreflexia, tremors, and a history of recent pesticide use in the field. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Organophosphate poisoning, due to inhibition of acetylcholinesterase

options.label: B
options.text: Organochlorine poisoning, due to disruption of the central nervous system

options.label: C
options.text: Carbamate poisoning, which affects the cholinergic system similarly to organophosphates

options.label: D
options.text: Acute mercury poisoning, leading to neurological and gastrointestinal symptoms

questions.correct_answer: B. Organochlorine poisoning, due to disruption of the central nervous system
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Organochlorine poisoning, due to disruption of the central nervous system.

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual diagnosed with schizophrenia commits an act that would otherwise be considered a criminal offense. The act was committed during a period of acute psychotic episode. The individual's medical history indicates sporadic adherence to prescribed antipsychotic medication. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the criminal responsibility of mentally ill?

options.label: A
options.text: Accused will be responsible since the act was committed while not adhering to prescribed medication.

options.label: B
options.text: Accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.

options.label: C
options.text: Accused will be responsible due to the sporadic nature of the individual's symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: The accused will not be responsible only if the act was committed during a state of complete unconsciousness.

questions.correct_answer: B. Accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.

questions.text: Which of the following is a critical management step if a body packer presents with suspected rupture of a drug-filled packet in the gastrointestinal tract?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate induction of vomiting to expel the drugs from the stomach

options.label: B
options.text: Administration of activated charcoal to absorb any remaining drugs in the gastrointestinal tract

options.label: C
options.text: Urgent imaging to identify the location and number of packets, followed by possible surgical intervention

options.label: D
options.text: Intravenous naloxone to reverse potential opioid overdose symptoms

questions.correct_answer: C. Urgent imaging to identify the location and number of packets, followed by possible surgical intervention
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Urgent imaging to identify the location and number of packets, followed by possible surgical intervention

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate statement about metal fume fever?

options.label: A
options.text: Metal fume fever is a chronic condition that results from long-term, low-level exposure to heavy metals like cadmium and lead, and is characterized by neurological damage.

options.label: B
options.text: The condition is caused by inhalation of metal oxide fumes, particularly zinc oxide, during activities like welding or galvanizing, leading to flu-like symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: The primary symptom of metal fume fever is persistent cough and shortness of breath, which may lead to permanent lung damage if untreated.

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C

questions.correct_answer: B. The condition is caused by inhalation of metal oxide fumes, particularly zinc oxide, during activities like welding or galvanizing, leading to flu-like symptoms.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The condition is caused by inhalation of metal oxide fumes, particularly zinc oxide, during activities like welding or galvanizing, leading to flu-like symptoms

questions.text: A 40-year-old university professor has been charged with the serious assault of a colleague. Professor has been battling untreated schizophrenia, characterized by profound auditory hallucinations and delusions. On the day in question, he was under the delusion that his colleague was a covert agent sent to harm him, leading to the assault. According to Indian law, how should the professor's criminal responsibility be assessed?

options.label: A
options.text: He is responsible because he was conscious of his physical actions during the assault.

options.label: B
options.text: He is not responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.

options.label: C
options.text: He is responsible because the act was a result of a deliberate decision, despite his mental illness.

options.label: D
options.text: He is responsible because his mental illness does not excuse violent behavior.

questions.correct_answer: B. He is not responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) He is not responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios would be most likely to result in heteropaternal superfetation?

options.label: A
options.text: A woman ovulates and conceives during two separate cycles, with one fertilization occurring after intercourse with a different partner in the second cycle

options.label: B
options.text: A woman ovulates once but is fertilized twice by sperm from the same partner during a prolonged sexual encounter

options.label: C
options.text: A woman has two eggs released from the same ovulatory cycle and both fertilized by sperm from the same partner

options.label: D
options.text: A woman has two fertilized eggs from the same ovulation cycle, both from the same partner, with a delayed implantation

questions.correct_answer: A. A woman ovulates and conceives during two separate cycles, with one fertilization occurring after intercourse with a different partner in the second cycle
questions.explanation: Ans. A) A woman ovulates and conceives during two separate cycles, with one fertilization occurring after intercourse with a different partner in the second cycle

questions.text: Identify the plant given in the image below?

options.label: A
options.text: Datura alba

options.label: B
options.text: Argemone mexicana

options.label: C
options.text: Abrus precatorius

options.label: D
options.text: Erthyroxylum coca

questions.correct_answer: B. Argemone mexicana
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Argemone mexicana

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of paradoxical undressing in individuals who die from hypothermia?

options.label: A
options.text: Sudden vasodilation in the extremities causes a false sensation of warmth, leading to the removal of clothing.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain's temperature regulation center becomes impaired, causing the person to misinterpret the environment and undress.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased shivering causes discomfort, prompting the person to remove clothing to cool down.

options.label: D
options.text: A reduction in blood flow to the muscles causes extreme fatigue, leading to an involuntary removal of clothing.

questions.correct_answer: B. The brain's temperature regulation center becomes impaired, causing the person to misinterpret the environment and undress.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The brain's temperature regulation center becomes impaired, causing the person to misinterpret the environment and undress.

questions.text: Treatment of methanol poisoning includes all except:

options.label: A
options.text: Ethanol

options.label: B
options.text: Fomepizole

options.label: C
options.text: Hemodialysis

options.label: D
options.text: Forced Alkaline Diuresis

questions.correct_answer: D. Forced Alkaline Diuresis
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Forced Alkaline Diuresis

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department of a district hospital by his coworkers after collapsing in an industrial area known for chemical manufacturing. Upon regaining consciousness, the medical officer notes that the patient exhibits no apparent physical injuries, but there is a distinct "rotten egg" odor on his breath. The patient's vital signs are stable. Considering the industrial setting and the specific odor described, what is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Carbon monoxide poisoning

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrogen sulphide poisoning

options.label: C
options.text: Cyanide toxicity

options.label: D
options.text: Ammonia inhalation

questions.correct_answer: B. Hydrogen sulphide poisoning
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Hydrogen sulphide poisoning

questions.text: Why do leg cramps occur during physical exertion in heat?

options.label: A
options.text: Dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, particularly low sodium levels, disrupt normal muscle function, leading to cramps.

options.label: B
options.text: High body temperature causes blood vessels in the legs to constrict, reducing blood flow and resulting in muscle cramps.

options.label: C
options.text: Excessive sweating causes the accumulation of lactic acid in muscles, which triggers cramping.

options.label: D
options.text: Overuse of muscles in hot conditions leads to muscle fatigue, causing cramps due to insufficient oxygen supply.

questions.correct_answer: A. Dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, particularly low sodium levels, disrupt normal muscle function, leading to cramps.
questions.explanation: Ans. A)

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer is brought to emergency department by his family after he ingested a rodenticide containing aluminum phosphide (alphos). He presents with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and dizziness. ECG shows arrhythmias, and laboratory tests indicate signs of organ toxicity. Medical officer initiates treatment with magnesium sulfate. What is the primary role of magnesium sulfate in the treatment of this patient's alphos poisoning?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduction of organ toxicity and correction of arrhythmias

options.label: B
options.text: Enhancement of phosphine excretion

options.label: C
options.text: Prevention of gastric acidity and liberation of phosphine gas

options.label: D
options.text: Correction of metabolic acidosis

questions.correct_answer: A. Reduction of organ toxicity and correction of arrhythmias
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Reduction of organ toxicity and correction of arrhythmias

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents after ingesting a large quantity of aconite from a herbal preparation. She reports symptoms of dizziness, nausea, and muscle weakness. On examination, her blood pressure is low, and she is found to have bradycardia. She also has perioral numbness. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism responsible for the symptoms in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Inhibition of acetylcholinesterase, leading to continuous acetylcholine stimulation.

options.label: B
options.text: Blocking of sodium channels, disrupting action potentials in the heart and nerves.

options.label: C
options.text: Stimulation of alpha-adrenergic receptors, causing vasoconstriction and hypertension.

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibition of serotonin reuptake, causing excessive serotonin accumulation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Blocking of sodium channels, disrupting action potentials in the heart and nerves.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Blocking of sodium channels, disrupting action potentials in the heart and nerves.
